Graphical abstract This review provides a systematic summary of active phosphides as promoters for Li–S chemistry, aiming at helping to understanding the working mechanism of phosphide promoters and guiding the design of advanced Li–S batteries. Li–S batteries have been considered as one of advanced next-generation energy storage systems owing to their remarkable theoretical capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1). However, critical issues, mainly pertaining to lithium polysulfide shuttle and slow sulfur reaction kinetics, have posed a fatal threat to the electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries. The situation is even worse for high sulfur-loaded and flexible cathodes, which are the essential components for practical Li–S batteries. In response, the use of metal compounds as electrocatalysts in Li–S systems have been confirmed as an effective strategy to date. Particularly, recent years have witnessed many progresses in phosphides-optimized Li–S chemistry. This has been motivated by the superior electron conductivity and high electrocatalytic activity of phosphides. In this tutorial review, we offer a systematic summary of active metal phosphides as promoters for Li–S chemistry, aiming at helping to understanding the working mechanism of phosphide electrocatalysts and guiding the construction of advanced Li–S batteries. Keywords Metal phosphides Li–S chemistry Polysulfide regulation Electrocatalysis 1 Introduction The rapid development of portable electronic devices has greatly inspired the demand for state-of-the-art battery systems. Lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries are proved as an emerging energy storage system for real applications due to their merits of high theoretical capacity (1672 mAh g−1), outstanding energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), low cost as well as earth abundance of sulfur (Fig. 1 ) [1,2]. Despite the relatively great progress made thus far, there still remain issues, mainly pertaining to electronic/ionic insulation of sulfur, notorious lithium polysulfide (LiPS) shuttle and suppressed reaction kinetics, leading to fast capacity degradation and inferior lifespan of Li–S batteries [3,4]. These issues, originating from the intrinsic features of sulfur, are expected to be tackled in an academic investigation and practical application of Li–S batteries. In recent years, investigation interests have been centered on the construction of high-efficiency sulfur cathodes by applying polar metal compounds (MCs) encompassing oxides [5–7], sulfides [8–10], carbides [11–13] and nitrides [14–16] to address the aforementioned issues. In contrast with carbon-based mediators such as nanotubes (CNTs) and graphene, MCs provide abundant polar sites suitable for chemical adsorption of LiPSs. There are different functions for nonconductive (oxides) and conductive (sulfides, carbides and nitrides) MCs in Li–S chemistry. Pioneering work by Cui’s group confirmed the monolayered chemisorption of LiPSs on oxides and further revealed their function of balanced management between LiPSs-adsorption and diffusion [17]. Typically, Li2S nucleation reaction kinetics is dominated by the interfacial charge conductivity on mediators [18]. For nonconductive oxides, the Li2S nucleation reaction manages to occur on the near conductive mediators. Therefore, it’s difficult for nonconductive MCs such as oxides to well adjust to the LiPS evolution. The recent work by us and others also demonstrated the unsatisfied efficiency of TiO2 [19], V2O3 [20], Co3O4 [21], etc., in rationalizing electrocatalysis of Li–S chemistry. Additionally, the usage of nonconducting MCs is quite low in the whole cathode, limiting their optimizing effect on battery system. In contrast to nonconductive MCs, conductive MCs display superior electrocatalytic functions in sulfur reaction process due to their electron conductive surface, implying their greater potential in enhancing the electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries. Additionally, the favorable electron conductivity also indicates that conductive MCs can completely serve as sulfur hosts rather than additives in cathodes. Take sulfides as an example. Firstly, the charge conductivity of sulfides is beneficial to the direct Li2S nucleation reaction on their surfaces during discharging process. Secondly, the interaction between sulfur in sulfides and isolated Li+ induces low overpotential, reducing the decomposition energy barrier for Li2S in the charging process [22]. Carbides and nitrides also present more favorable catalytic functions owing to their superior conductivity. In this respect, our recent work also reported that VS2 [23], VN [24] and Ti3C2 [25] managed to alleviate LiPS shuttle and accelerate sulfur reaction kinetics, thereby enhancing the rate and cycling performances of battery systems. Therefore, the sulfur redox mechanism is hindered for nonconductive mediators. Conductive MCs can realize the comprehensive regulation of LiPSs-adsorption, diffusion and conversion on their surfaces, implying that they can act as both effective LiPS immobilizers and electrocatalysts for Li–S chemistry. Metal phosphides have aroused considerable interests in the fields of oxygen evolution reaction [26], water splitting [27] and photocatalytic conversion [28] due to their outstanding conductivity and remarkable electrocatalysis property. More recently, phosphides such as FeP [29], CoP [30], Ni2P [31], Sn4P3 [32], have been largely investigated as emerging electrocatalysts for Li–S battery systems. In contrast with other MCs, phosphides possess the following advantages: (i) Showing metallic characteristics and even superconductivity; (ii) being obtained by facile and gentle synthesis procedures. As a result, phosphides can serve as promising candidates for Li–S battery applications. Moreover, the recent mechanism explorations also reveal the superb ability of phosphides in realizing the coupling of interfacial ions and electrons, as well as regulating LiPS evolution, which is anticipated to guide the rational construction of advanced Li–S batteries [33,34]. In spite of many instructive overviews in the realm of Li–S batteries, there have been rarely reviews that cover the current advances and future directions of phosphides targeted commercially viable Li–S systems. This review herein aims to offer a comprehensive and insightful summary of the current progresses in phosphides-enabled Li–S chemistry, including in-depth elucidation of design principles and mechanistic electrocatalysis functions as well as pragmatic perspectives. 2 LiPS evolution and challenges Sulfur species comprise of octasulfur (S8), soluble high-order Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8) as well as insoluble low-order Li2S2/Li2S [35]. Despite extensive efforts have been paid, there is still a long way to go for Li–S batteries to meet practical requirements. Compared with commercial lithium-ion batteries, Li–S batteries present a more complicated electrochemical reaction process experiencing dissolution and multistep phase conversion of sulfur species. Such a special evolution approach causes several critical challenges, mainly pertaining to the dissolution, shuttle of LiPSs as well as retarded sulfur reaction kinetics, thus leading to resultant inferior electrochemical performances of battery systems (Fig. 2 ) [36]. Before comprehensively elucidating the working mechanism of phosphides, deep understandings of these key challenges are prerequisite. 2.1 LiPS dissolution S8 presents the most stable state among sulfur allotropes. However, it suffers from the reduction into soluble high-order LiPSs and final transformation into insoluble low-order Li2S/Li2S2 during the discharging process. Such conversion reaction occurs at the interface between sulfur and host material, which represents the typical pathway of sulfur evolution. Current evidences have substantiated that the LiPS dissolution strongly correlates with LiPS shuttle and electrochemical reaction kinetics [37–39]. Moreover, continuous and repetitive dissolution-deposition of S8 leads to the structural collapse of cathode during the long-term cycles. In response, many efforts have been made to relieve the dissolution of LiPSs into electrolyte [40]. Developing new electrolytes such as solid-state [41] and ionic liquid types [42] have been proposed as effective strategies by kinetically suppressing the migration of LiPSs and thermo-dynamically restraining their dissolution. However, such electrolyte strategies are subjected to low ionic conductivity at ambient temperature, resulting in suppressed sulfur reaction process and thus unsatisfied battery performances [42]. The saturated solubility of LiPSs sets an upper bound on LiPS dissolution especially at a low electrolyte/sulfur ratio. In light of this, lowering the dosage of electrolyte in battery system is also an alternative solution [43]. Nevertheless, sulfur cathode displays slow Li+ diffusion under an electrolyte-lean condition, leading to low sulfur utilization and large polarization, accompanied by deficient electrochemical reaction. In addition, the critical problem of LiPS dissolution can be diminished by chemically tailoring the LiPS into confined allotropes [40]. In this fashion, these allotropes can directly convert into Li2S2 and Li2S without the generation of soluble LiPSs [44]. Such a LiPS formation blocking strategy opens up a new door to optimize the pathway of LiPS evolution and thereby benefits to solving the problem of LiPS dissolution. 2.2 LiPS shuttle In a typical Li–S system, soluble LiPS migrating back and forth between electrodes is so-called “LiPS shuttle”, which gives rise to the irreversible sulfur loss, continuous anode corrosion and amplified electrolyte decomposition, thus leading to low discharge capacity and inferior cycling stability of batteries [3]. Such shuttle behavior of LiPSs results from the comprehensive effect of both electric field and concentration gradients of LiPSs between electrodes, manifesting a formidable challenge in the realms of thermodynamics and kinetics. Therefore, improved mitigation of LiPS shuttle is thus essential to acquire satisfactory performances of batteries. Along this line, the current strategies dealing with LiPS shuttle can be divided into the following categories: physical confinement, chemical entrapment and their synergy. Carbonaceous materials such as CNTs, graphene present physical affinity with polar LiPSs. The hollow capsule design of mediators can encapsulate and sequester sulfur into their interior shell, paving a new way to physically confine the migration of LiPSs [45]. However, such physical confinement is far from satisfactory to alleviate LiPS shuttling. Heteroatom doping can increase the number of polar sites of carbonaceous materials, nevertheless, it’s quite difficult to achieve doping concentration beyond 10 atom% [46,47]. As such, polar mediators such as MCs, polymers with functional groups present more distinct advantages in retarding LiPS shuttle. Of particular note, MCs have displayed great potential to overcome the shuttle problem by their polar interaction with LiPSs. The synergy of physical confinement and chemical entrapment can guarantee the efficiency of suppressing LiPS shuttle. Zheng’s group constructed yolk–shelled Fe2N@C nanoboxes as sulfur host, showing the synergistic effect of physical confinement and chemical entrapment of LiPSs [14]. In our recent work, nepenthes-like nitrogen-doped graphene architectures were designed by applying a diatomite template to realize the dual immobilizations of LiPS shuttle [48]. We note that the current understandings in anchoring mechanism are by no means exhaustive and only indicate the physical confinement or chemical adsorption of mediators. Therefore, the mechanism is still waiting to be further elucidated throughout continuous explorations from both theoretical simulations and experimental investigations. In this context, the recent work by us and others reported the reversible surface chemistry of “polysulfides-thiosulfate-polythionate” on certain unique MCs such as VO2 [49], Ti3C2 [50], manifesting a new way in parallel to the conventional chemical adsorption. Additionally, besides its contribution to relieving LiPS shuttle, the adsorption process also offers ample precursor source for subsequent Li2S nucleation, implying its important influence on sulfur reaction kinetics. 2.3 Retarded reaction kinetics The well-defined pathway of LiPS evolution dominates the discharging and charging processes, manifesting that retarded kinetics issues generates in both reduction and oxidation reactions. In general, the reversible liquid–liquid conversion of Li2S8 to Li2S4 shows a fast reaction kinetics. The kinetics issues mainly stem from the following processes: (i) The liquid–solid phase transformation of Li2S4 to Li2S; This transformation process delivers to nearly three quarters of the whole battery capacity, indicating the crucial stage of sulfur reaction. The electrolyte viscosity increases almost linearly along with the aforementioned liquid–liquid conversion of Li2S8 (6.00 mPa s) to Li2S4 (6.16 mPa s), leading to the retarded Li2S2 formation kinetics [51]. The solid–solid conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S contributes to about a half of the theoretical capacity [52]. Unfortunately, it suffers from slow solid-state diffusion, causing the early cessation of discharge, which leads to a large deviation between the real capacity and theoretical value [53]. Moreover, LiPS shuttle induces the uncontrollable deposition of Li2S on the surface of lithium anode, thus blocking the diffusion of Li+. Taken together, these factors, pertaining to electrolyte viscosity, solid-state diffusion as well as Li2S deposition on anode, gives rise to severe kinetics problem in the sulfur reduction process. (ii) The decomposition of Li2S. Li2S is subjected to quite low e– conductivity and relatively high Li+ migration resistance, which causes a high overpotential to deal with activation energy barrier at the initial charging stage, thereby slowing the sulfur oxidation reaction kinetics [54]. The above-mentioned kinetics issues limit the deep and high-rate discharge of battery systems, leading to a deficient electrochemical reaction process. Recently, many research studies have emphasized the vital role of electrocatalysts in rationalizing the sulfur redox reaction kinetics [55,56]. Sulfur redox reaction kinetics strongly depends on the “interaction”. Chiang’s group disclosed that the high interfacial interaction between Li2S and catalysts was beneficial to propelling Li2S nucleation reaction kinetics [54]. Cui’s group demonstrated that the Li2S decomposition energy barrier relied on the interaction between isolated Li+ and non-metallic atoms in catalysts [57]. As a result, stepwise electrocatalysis strategy based on well-defined electrocatalysts has a great potential to overcome these kinetics problems. The recent work by us reported that the heterostructural electrocatalysts such as VO2-VN [58], Graphene-TiO2 [19], VTe2-MgO [59] could accelerated the nucleation and growth of Li2S due to their balanced management of LiPS adsorption, diffusion and conversion. Sun’s group proposed the employment of amorphous CoS3 as a promoter to enable the reaction kinetics for solid–solid conversion from Li2S2 to Li2S [52]. The recent proposed catalytic mechanism of “lithium bond chemistry” also offered a rational strategy to facilitating sulfur oxidation reaction kinetics [60]. The kinetics issues have indeed posed a great threat to the practical application of Li–S batteries. However, these catalyst strategies can rationalize the electrocatalysis of Li–S chemistry and thus are anticipated to shed light upon the design of high-efficiency and long-life Li–S batteries. Additionally, in spite of scientific and technological viewpoints proposed thus far, the deep underlying mechanism of LiPS dissolution kinetics is still waiting to be further unveiled. In light of this, spotlight will continue to be centred on the development of new active electrocatalysts. 3 Phosphide strategy for Li–S chemistry The intrinsic issues hinder the realization of commercial Li–S batteries, including LiPS evolution, LiPS shuttle and suppressed sulfur reaction kinetics. Phosphides can serve as promising alternative hosts for Li–S chemistry owing to their effective regulation of LiPSs and high catalytic activity for sulfur redox reaction. Therefore, such phosphide strategy has attracted considerable attention to address the above issues thus far. This section focuses on the typical synthesis, working mechanism and design strategies of phosphides for promoted Li–S chemistry. 3.1 Typical synthesis routes for phosphides The synthesis of phosphides with tailored morphology, controllable structure and superb electron conductivity accounts for an ultimate pursuit for practical implementation in energy storage systems. Particularly in Li–S systems, the synthesis of phosphides has a vital impact on their both ability of LiPS management and high catalytic activity for sulfur redox reaction. Hence, it is well worth discussing the current synthesis routes for targeted phosphides. According to the diverse reaction phases, the typical routes for phosphides synthesis are divided into dry-chemistry and wet-chemistry approaches in this section (Fig. 3 ). 3.1.1 Dry-chemistry synthesis Over the past few years, dry-chemistry involving mechanical milling and annealing phosphidation have been regarded as the most commonly employed routes to prepare phosphides. The mechanical milling route is conducted by using hard balls to strongly mill the corresponding metal and red phosphorus precursors with certain stoichiometric amounts in an Ar-filled high energy mechanical milling vessel at room temperature [61]. The rotation and vibration originating from local collision of milling ball can significantly lower the reaction activation energy, refine the grains and improve the powder activity, thus leading to the production of phosphides [62]. By applying such mechanical milling procedure, phosphides such as Zn3P2 [63], CoP [64], GeP5 [62], Sn4+ x P3 [65], have been successfully synthesized for targeted energy storage application. It is noted that such mechanical milling route is easy-to-operate because of its gentle reaction temperature and simple precursor formulations. However, several drawbacks also are exhibited, including: (i) Dozens of hours of ball-milling time also build an obstacle to efficient production of phosphides; (ii) limited precursor sources imply the scarce types of phosphides. Thus far, annealing phosphidation has served as a major paradigm to realize the synthesis of phosphides in the realm of Li–S batteries. Typically, annealing phosphidation is carried out by phosphating oxides or cyanides in a tube furnace at a high temperature exceeding 300 °C [66]. The current reported phosphorus sources mainly include NaH2PO2 [67], NH4H2PO4 [68] and PH3 [69]. Wang’s group employed Fe0.667Co(CN)4(H2O)4 as the metal precursor to prepare Co-Fe mixed metal phosphide as sulfur host [70]. The annealing phosphidation need only several hours to finish the phosphating reaction, manifesting higher phosphating efficiency in contrast with mechanical milling. However, such temperature-programmed phosphating reaction may cause the agglomeration of phosphides, thereby limiting their electrocatalytic activity to a certain extent. To optimize the dispersion and electron conductivity of phosphides, the hybrid structure comprising of phosphides and carbon mediators such as CNTs and graphene have also been widely developed throughout the process of annealing phosphidation. Wang’s group realized the conversion of CNT-Co3O4 to CNT-CoP and CNT-MoO3 to CNT-MoP, respectively, under the assistance of annealing phosphidation [71]. Note that the former directly occurred, however, the latter experienced a hydrogenation step before the phosphating reaction, indicating the tunable phosphating approaches. Yang’s group designed FeP/rGO/CNTs hybrid by high-temperature phosphating with NaH2PO2 as a phosphorus source [72]. The as-designed FeP/rGO/CNTs served as an effective electrocatalyst to promote LiPS redox reaction and thus improve the electrochemical performances of batteries. Such annealing phosphidation-enabled structure bridges the phosphides and carbon supports, which realizes the uniform distribution of active sites as well as long-range ordered electron conductivity, thereby showing a high electrocatalytic activity for Li–S chemistry. Along this line, the emerging MOF-derived carbon supported phosphides have received ever-growing attention. Such phosphorization treatment is usually performed at a temperature of 300–600 °C for 0.5–4.0 h [30,71,73]. The phosphating temperature is the key to the control of MOF-derived structure. Excessive temperature can cause the structural collapse and too low temperature may lead to the incomplete interconnected architectures. The MOF-enabled carbon frameworks provide superb support for the phosphides, leading to larger surface area, higher porosity and ampler heteroatom doping in contrast to phosphide/carbon hybrids derived from conventional precursors. As a result, MOF-derived carbon supported phosphides display multiple and abundant active sites to effectively suppress the LiPS shuttle and propel the sulfur reaction kinetics. Sun’s group phosphated MOF-74 (Ni) at 600 °C for 4.0 h to optimize the dispersion of Ni2P on 3D carbon frameworks [73]. The as-achieved Ni2P as sulfur host optimized the electrochemical reaction process and thus improved the battery performances even at a high sulfur loading of 4.6 mg cm−2. In this regard, Jin et al. developed MOF-derived hierarchical CoP as sulfur host to facilitate both the formation and decomposition of solid Li2S in discharging and charging process, respectively, thus enhancing the rate and cycling performances of Li–S batteries [74]. The MOF-derived interconnected frameworks not only realize the uniform distribution of active phosphides on carbon support but also offer favorable conductive network, which is beneficial to regulating the LiPSs and accelerating sulfur reaction kinetics. However, the preparation of MOF precursors is still throughout liquid-phase reaction, which might imply tunable but intricate procedures. The rich precursor sources and multi-pathways of annealing phosphidation are favorable for the synthesis of various phosphides. Therefore, annealing phosphidation still act as a versatile strategy for the rational design of phosphide electrocatalysts. 3.1.2 Wet-chemistry synthesis The wet-chemistry synthesis of phosphides refers to complex solution-phase reaction [75]. According to metal and phosphorus precursors, wet-chemistry synthesis mainly includes the two types: (i) The phosphating reaction of metal salts with phosphines to synthesize monodispersed phosphides; Song’s group realized the liquid-phase synthesis of Ni2P at a low temperature of 330 °C in a N2 atmosphere by using nickel acetylacetonate as nickel source, low-cost triphenylphosphine as phosphorus source and tri-n-octylamine as a solvent [76]. Such liquid-phase reaction can realize the synthesis of monodispersed phosphides, effectively avoiding the agglomeration of phosphides, which is beneficial to their functions of rationalizing Li–S chemistry. Furthermore, the morphologies of phosphides can be well controlled by the reductant, phosphorus source and dropping rate in such solution-phase reaction, leading to the tailorable morphology of phosphides for Li–S chemistry. (ii) The phosphating reaction of red phosphorus and metal compounds to hydrothermally prepare phosphides. Gao’s group designed a hydrothermal phosphating reaction of nickel chloride with red phosphorus at 180 °C to synthesize graphene supported Ni12P5 [77]. This hydrothermal synthetic route offers gentle conditions for the preparation of phosphides. However, there still remains challenge to obtain phosphides with high purity and superb electron conductivity throughout such a hydrothermal synthesis procedure. Comparison of typical routes for phosphide synthesis was listed in Table 1 . Wet-chemistry approach presents the advantages in preparing monodispersed phosphides under a facile phosphiding condition. Additionally, the structural characteristics of as-synthesized phosphides via wet-chemistry route are nearly compared with those of phosphides by dry-chemistry approach. However, dry-chemistry route acts as a general strategy of realizing the phosphiding synthesis due to their rich precursor sources and scalable synthetic pathways. Despite of various phosphides prepared by the aforementioned typical routes, it is still very desirable to develop novel approaches featuring tunable conditions and versatile techniques to synthesize active phosphide electrocatalysts for Li–S chemistry. 3.2 LiPS management by phosphides One of the keys to advanced Li–S batteries lies in the efficient immobilization of LiPSs within the cathode side. As such, it is of profound significance to highlight the management of LiPS behaviors by phosphides. Beyond nonpolar carbonaceous materials, phosphides present intrinsic polarity, where phosphorus and metal ions synergistically bind with Li+ and S n 2− ions, manifesting their promising capability to effectively mitigate LiPS shuttle. Zhang et al. reported the chemical adsorption of sulfur species on FeP (Fig. 4 a and b) [29]. According to their calculation result, the adsorption energies (E a) of S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2 and Li2S on the FeP facet (111) are −2.833, −3.071, −3.000, −1.975, −4.210 and −2.566 eV, respectively (Fig. 4a). Furthermore, the ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) test result shows the quick fade of Li2S6 adsorption signal in the visible light window due to the introduction of FeP/rGO, indicating the strong anchoring ability of FeP (Fig. 4b). Chen’s group disclosed the interaction between LiPSs and CoP/HPCN by a series of systematical characterizations (Fig. 4c–g) [30]. Both theoretical simulations and visual adsorption tests verify the strong affinity of CoP with LiPSs. Moreover, the formation of Co–S bond and backward shift of all the Co 2p3/2 peaks in XPS spectra further corroborated the effective anchoring ability of CoP with LiPSs. Such strong polar-polar interaction between phosphides and LiPSs is critically important to the effective suppression of shuttle effect. The typical application of phosphides in Li–S battery system involves sulfur host within cathode and interlayer between electrodes. A routine separator possesses abundant pores with sizes of several hundred nanometres, which allows soluble LiPSs of size less than 2.0 nm to freely pass through, further intensifying the LiPS shuttle. The interlayer design lies in the coating functional materials on one side of a traditional separator, exhibiting dense packing structure and polar surface to synergize bifunctionality of physical blockage and chemical capture toward LiPSs. In this respect, considerable attempts centred on the rational construction of advanced interlayers at the early stage of phosphide immobilizer studies, where Ni2P [31] and MoP2 [83] were employed to modify the separators. The latest work by Ye et al. devised a dual-adsorption interlayer composed of porous carbon/Sn4P3 nanodots to deal with the LiPS shuttle problem (Fig. 5 ) [32]. Thus-designed interlayer shows a thickness of ~ 4.0 μm with a mass loading of 0.1–0.2 mg cm−2, implying that it not only served an effective physical LiPS barrier but also acted as a chemical LiPS scavenger. Operando Raman spectroscopy allows the online state of sulfur species to be directly detected in a working Li–S battery state. According to the collected operando Raman spectra, the gradual attenuation of sulfur species signals upon discharge reflected the effective alleviation of shuttle effect by such a carbon/Sn4P3 interlayer. The use of phosphides in interlayer design enables fine control over the LiPS behaviors toward the realization of high-performance Li–S batteries. In contrast to binding strength, anchoring efficiency serves as a more direct evidence to evaluate the LiPS adsorption ability of immobilizers. Along this line, the anchoring efficiency of MCs involving oxides, sulfides, nitrides and phosphides based on visual LiPS adsorption tests was listed in Table 2 . It is worth mentioning that these visual LiPS adsorption tests by using different types and usages of sulfur species reflect the anchoring efficiency objectively due to their same evaluating criteria. As seen from Table 2, in comparison with the recent reported MCs for Li–S system, phosphides show favorable adsorption efficiency. Zhou et al. compared the anchoring abilities of a series of Co-based compounds involving Co3O4, CoS2, Co4N and CoP toward Li2S6 (Fig. 6 a) [33]. The binding energies (E b) between Li2S6 and Co3O4 (001), CoS2 (001), Co4N (111), CoP (211) are calculated to be 5.00, 1.84, 9.67 and 4.13 eV, respectively. CoS2 shows the weakest adsorbility, while Co4N displays the strongest adsorbility, and CoP presents moderate adsorbility of Li2S6. Generally, weak affinity of immobilizers with LiPSs is insufficient to the suppression of shuttle effect. However, too strong adsorption of LiPSs on MCs may lead to the broken Li–S bonds and the irreversibility of LiPS conversion. The author also confirmed the partial sulfurization of Co4N surface because of its too strong adsorption. From this point of view, CoP can still act as one of the ideal LiPS immobilizers. The anchoring efficiency arises from the comprehensive regulation of surface reactivity, binding strength with LiPSs and surface area of MCs. And in this respect, phosphides indeed offer abundant polar sites for anchoring LiPSs, showing a compared efficiency with other MCs for LiPS management. To further extend the anchoring efficiency toward LiPSs within a rational range, phosphides with tailored architectures have been developed as well. The previous studies have provided us a rational guideline to tailor the structures and morphologies of phosphides [55]. Such as-designed phosphides can realize the synergy of physical blockage and chemical entrapment toward LiPSs, exhibiting outstanding ability of alleviating LiPS shuttle. Cheng et al. designed a unique Ni2P yolk–shell nanosphere as sulfur host for LiPS management (Fig. 6b) [96]. The sulfur was encapsulated and sequestered into the interior shell of hollow Ni2P capsules, leading to the following advantages for sulfur regulation: (i) Maximizing the mass loading of sulfur targeted practical application; (ii) effectively relieving the volume variation of cathode over long-term cycling; (iii) physical confining the LiPS migration due to the hollow capsules; (vi) chemical suppressing the LiPS shuttle owing to its ample polar sites. Such a versatile design has been proved as a viable strategy to extend the anchoring efficiency. As such, template-confined synthesis alternatively acts as a facile and scalable approach for achieving phosphides with tailored architectures. Additionally, the “Goldilocks” principle, pertaining to the above-mentioned reversible polysulfide-thiosulfate-polythionate conversion on the surface of several types of MCs, has gained novel insights into the mechanism exploration of highly efficient management of LiPS behaviors [97]. However, there is no evidence to suggest such surface chemical catenation of LiPSs existing on the surface of phosphides thus far. Hence, the surface realities of phosphides are waiting to be revealed by systematically evaluating their redox potentials under real operation conditions as well as chemical compositions after LiPS adsorption. 3.3 Promoted Li–S chemistry by phosphides The activity of electrocatalysts lies in efficiently propelling the kinetic conversion of LiPSs and thereby boosting the electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries. Aiming for readers who are interested in the realm of electrocatalysts-enabled Li–S chemistry investigations, this section focuses scope on the electrocatalysis of phosphides for sulfur redox reaction to elucidate the catalytic mechanism and design strategies of phosphides toward the rational design of highly efficient electrochemical reaction process of Li–S batteries. 3.3.1 The electrocatalytic behaviors The intrinsic characters of sulfur and evolution behaviors of LiPSs cause the fatal drawbacks encompassing relatively low ionic and electronic conductivities, restricting the electrochemical reaction kinetics of Li–S batteries [98]. Especially under the real scenarios of high sulfur loading, lean electrolyte usage or flexibility, the battery systems have to deal with more formidable reaction kinetics problems, which call for highly active electrocatalysts to rationalize Li–S chemistry [99]. Of the many alternatives, phosphides have been widely employed to increase the sulfur redox reaction rates due to their high electrocatalytic activity. Inspired by the pioneer work from Tao et al. designing a series of phosphide electrocatalysts (Ni2P, Co2P and Fe2P) to optimize Li–S chemistry [100], fruitful achievements have been made to reveal the catalytic mechanism of phosphides for sulfur reaction processes [29,67]. In consideration of the nature of multi-electron and multi-ion conversion chemistry, the electrocatalytic activity of phosphides can be elucidated by discussing their electron conductivity, ion transfer property and LiPS anchoring ability. The electron conductivity of electrocatalysts plays a critical role in accelerating the electrochemical reaction kinetics of Li–S batteries. In view of conductivity, there may be very limited candidates to be used as sulfur hosts. It is noted that the P atoms present strong electronegativity, implying that decreasing the atomic ratio of P and metal can enable the electron delocalization in metal and hence endows phosphides with more remarkable electron conductivity. Yu and coworkers realized the synthesis of Ni-rich phosphide (Ni12P5) with a higher electron conductivity compared with Ni-poor phosphide (Ni2P) as an active electrocatalyst for Li–S chemistry [101]. Such a tuning strategy at atomic level offer new insights into improving the electrocatalytic activity of phosphides. Except for electron and ion conductivity, the LiPS anchoring ability of electrocatalysts also has a crucial impact on sulfur reaction process. Firstly, the excellent LiPS anchoring ability guarantees the abundant precursor sources on-site ready the Li2S nucleation reaction. Additionally, latest elucidation with respect to the mechanism of Li2S nucleation has been proposed by Chiang’s group [54]. This fundamental chemistry of classical crystal growth unraveled that the capacity of Li2S deposition directly correlated with the interfacial binding between substrates and Li2S. A recent work by Huang et al. reported that the large binding energy value of –1.98 eV between FeP (111) and Li2S leaded to a higher capacity (238.6 mAh g−1) of Li2S deposition, further demonstrating the favorable catalytic ability of FeP [72]. More recently, the electrocatalytic behaviors of phosphides for Li–S chemistry were also decoded by band engineering. Zhou et al. confirmed the higher electrocatalytic activity of CoP in contrast with other Co-based compounds encompassing Co3O4, CoS2 and Co4N (Fig. 7 a) [33]. They proposed that the high catalytic activity of CoP stemmed from the shift of p band centers, which realized the modulation of interfacial migration dynamics. The latest work led by Zhu et al. further disclosed that the p band shift-enabled the interfacial electronics transfer could be realized by increasing the electronic concentration on the fermi level of adsorbed Li2S4 (Fig. 7b) [24]. These valuable findings of p band concept reveal the fundamental modulation principles for the phosphide-tuned kinetic behaviors of LiPSs, manifesting the great potential of band engineering for rational design of high-performance Li–S batteries. Phosphides exhibit high electrocatalytic activity for Li–S chemistry and boost the electrochemical performances of battery systems due to their comprehensive management of LiPS adsorption ability, Li+ diffusion and e– transfer properties (Table 3 ). To build up a high-efficiency Li–S chemistry system, persistent efforts have been devoted to extending the catalytic activity of phosphides. In this section, we also center on the corresponding effective strategies comprising of site-rich and binary catalysis through the rational design of phosphide electrocatalysts. 3.3.2 Site-rich catalysis In order to further improve the electrocatalytic efficiency of phosphides, site-rich catalysis strategy has been proposed to date. In general, the catalytic efficiency of promoters is closely related to their specific surface area [107]. As such, phosphides with high surface area can offer abundant active sites to accelerate Li–S chemistry. In this respect, template-derived phosphides have a tendency to perfectly inherit from the template experiencing chemical preparing reactions, realizing a high surface area and thus site-rich catalysis for sulfur redox reaction kinetics. Considering the impact of template removal on the chemical stability of phosphides, ideal templates in combination with gently removing approach is highly expected. Due to their thermodynamic metastable state, phosphides tend to agglomerate, which restricts their electrocatalytic abilities to a large extent. To tackle this concern, the carbon frameworks as an ideal support can realize the homogeneous distribution of phosphides and long-range ordered electron conductivity, providing a site-rich catalysis strategy for Li–S chemistry. A recent work by us reported the growth of CoP on graphene flakes to obtain a highly active electrocatalyst for LiPS conversion reaction (Fig. 8 ) [74]. Owing to such rational design, the CoP/graphene-S (CoP/G-S) cathodes showed a faster sulfur reaction kinetics and more favorable electrochemical reversibility than CoP/S cathode. It is worth-noting from Fig. 8(c) that the capacity of Li2S precipitation on CoP/G reaches 219.54 mAh gS –1, the value of which is 1.6 folds in contrast to that of CoP (134.17 mAh gS –1). As expected, the battery harvested high rate capacities and stable cycling performance even under the conditions of high sulfur loadings and flexible pouch cells. Guang et al. proposed a scalable strategy to construct P-doped carbon with built-in Ni2P particles (CNT@NP) as an effective promoter for Li–S chemistry [31]. The uniform distribution of Ni2P on carbon skeleton gave rise to ample active sites for facilitating LiPS conversion reaction. Benefiting from such site-rich catalysis strategy, the cathode maintained a low capacity decay of only 0.077% per cycle over 500 cycles at 1.0 C. The site-rich catalysis strategy allows the full use of phosphide electrocatalysts to enable the sulfur redox reaction kinetics and hence optimize the battery performances, holding great promise in the future real implementation of Li–S batteries. 3.3.3 Binary catalysis Motivated by the emerging heterointerface engineering with respect to the rational design of binary catalysts [108,109], binary catalysis based on phosphides have been developed thus far as another useful strategy to propel the formation and decomposition of Li2S in discharge and charge procedures, respectively [70,110]. The mechanism of binary catalysis lies in realizing the synergy and division catalysis of components targeted highly efficient Li–S chemistry. Chen et al. developed uniform Co–Fe mixed metal phosphide (Co–Fe–P) to address the main drawbacks of Li–S systems (Fig. 9 ) [70]. The Co–Fe–P provided two types of metal centers, which caused the generation of strong Fe–S and Co–S bonds, leading to the efficient LiPS adsorption and rich precursor sources for subsequent Li2S nucleation reaction. Benefiting from the polar surface, superb electron conductivity and abundant contact surface, Co–Fe–P offered ample sites for managing LiPSs and catalyzing the sulfur redox reaction kinetics. With these advantages, the cathode harvests a high sulfur utilization efficiency and remained a low capacity decay of 0.043% over 500 cycles at 1.0 C. Even under the practical conditions of high sulfur loadings (≥5.5 mg cm−2) and soft-package cells, the cathode still delivers favorable electrochemical performances. The true active phase of metal-based catalysts including phosphides and nitrides in Li–S batteries, pertaining to their surface oxide layer [111] or in-situ evolved sulfide phase [112], indeed plays an important role in the promoting sulfur redox reaction kinetics. Such a catalyst design principle lies in making use of the reactive features of MCs to construct binary catalysts with high activity. The heterostructure can combine the functions of components, offering a new approach for addressing the complicated Li–S battery systems. The air-sensitive feature of conductive MCs implies that the superficial oxidation of phosphides has a great potential to activate the surface metal centers for promoting LiPS evolution. Zhong et al. reported the important role of surface chemistry in CoP-stabilized Li–S batteries (Fig. 10 a) [111]. Such delicate heterostructure presented the following merits: (i) The surface oxidation layer triggered the strong adsorption of LiPS; (ii) the inner core of CoP served as a superb electron conductor; (iii) the compact interface contact was beneficial to favorable for LiPS diffusion. As a result, the cathode with a high sulfur loading of 7.0 mg cm−2 exhibits a fast reaction kinetics process and thereby held a high areal capacity of 5.6 mAh cm−2 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C. Such a heterostructural design further elevates the electrocatalytic activity of phosphides and represents a typical strategy of binary catalysis. Shen et al. reported a highly active Ni2Co4P3 promoter for Li–S chemistry (Fig. 10b) [80]. The as-constructed Ni2Co4P3 could weaken the S–S bonds and decrease the activation barrier of LiPS conversion, thereby resulting in a higher electrocatalytic activity of Ni2Co4P3 in contrast with Ni2P. As shown in Fig. 10b, Ni2Co4P3 obtains a higher capacity of Li2S deposition (175.4 mAh gS –1) compared with Ni2P (103.5 mAh gS –1), further confirming the superior catalytic ability of Ni2Co4P3. Such binary catalysis strategies can realize the balanced regulation of chemical anchoring ability, Li+ migration and e– transfer properties of phosphides, which is beneficial to building up a smooth LiPS “adsorption-diffusion-conversion” process, thus accelerating the electrochemical reaction procedures of Li–S batteries. The existing investigations have attempted to study the electrocatalysis pathways of binary or heterostructural phosphides in a working Li–S battery. However, the corresponding synergy and division catalysis mechanism in Li–S chemistry is still waiting to be further disclosed. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Li–S batteries indeed can serve as a promising alternative for Li–ion batteries. However, the fatal LiPS shuttle and formidable sulfur reaction kinetics problems give rise to inferior electrochemical performances, limiting the real application of Li–S batteries. The use of MC electrocatalysts is deemed to be an effective solution to mitigating the shuttle effect and promoting sulfur reaction kinetics. Of particularly note, phosphides act as superior promoters for Li–S chemistry because of their superb electron conductivity, moderate LiPS adsorption ability and high electrocatalytic activity. The well-defined design principle and in-depth catalytic mechanism explorations with respect to phosphides have provided valuable guidelines to the construction of high-efficiency and long-lifespan Li–S batteries. Nevertheless, there are still many spaces for persistent explorations in phosphide promoters. These include, but not limited to, the following (Fig. 11 ): (i) The phosphides with high electrocatalytic activity need to be further innovated. The current limited types of phosphide electrocatalysts result in lack of in-depth research on phosphides-enabled Li–S systems. The optimized synthesis routes would be appealing to construct highly active phosphides accordingly. Additionally, defect or interface engineering on phosphides for accelerated Li–S chemistry are highly expected to implement. (ii) The electrocatalytic mechanism of phosphides need to be deeply revealed. A clear electrocatalytic mechanism understanding is beneficial to constructing phosphide promoters with high electrocatalytic activity. Despite many efforts devoted to detecting the catalytic functions of phosphides, the contribution of strong LiPS adsorption, coupling of Li+ and e– as well as electrocatalytic pathways based on phosphide promoters are waiting to be probed. (iii) The working mechanism of phosphides on metal lithium anodes need to be explored. The rapid decay of metal lithium anodes impedes the electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries [113,114]. As a result, deep investigation of phosphides-optimized lithium anodes is beneficial to completely understanding the working mechanism of phosphides on Li–S chemistry and realizing the rational design of advanced of Li–S batteries. (iv) Advanced in-situ characterization techniques need to be extensively developed. Several important in-situ optical techniques such as Raman, infrared and UV–vis spectroscopies have been employed to record the real-time reaction process of Li–S systems. However, there still remains challenge in clearly evaluating the real state of LiPSs due to their electrochemical instability and the limited resolution of instruments. Therefore, advanced in-situ characterization techniques including but not limited to, X-ray absorption (XAS), small angle neutron scattering (SANS) and their combinations with optical techniques are in great demand to paint the landscape of Li–S chemistry. (v) The real application of Li–S batteries is expected to be further promoted by active phosphide electrocatalysts. The real application scenarios, pertaining to high sulfur loadings, lean electrolyte usage and flexibility, cause relatively intricate sulfur reaction process, leading to inferior electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries. High-performance Li–S chemistry systems toward future commercial application might be realized by applying active phosphide electrocatalysts. In summary, the use of phosphide promoters indeed serves as an effective strategy to optimize the electrochemical reaction approach and design high-energy density and long-lifespan Li–S batteries. However, a multitude of challenges with regard to advanced Li–S system construction is still expected to be addressed throughout persistent efforts from both experimental and theoretical explorations. Huang, X.Q. Zhang, C. Yan, Q. Zhang, J. Energy Chem. 37 (2019) 29–34. Son g lin Yu received his B.S. degree from Southwest University of Science and Technology in 2018. Now he is a master candidate in State Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Energy Materials, Southwest University of Science and Technology under the supervision of Prof. Yingze Song and associate Prof. Lixian Song. His research interests focus on active electrocatalysts for Li–S chemistry. Wenlong Cai received his B.S. degree from Sichuan University in 2013 and Ph.D. from University of Science and Technology of China in 2019. He joined Prof. Qiang Zhang's research group as a postdoctoral research fellow at the Department of Chemical Engineering in Tsinghua University. His current research interests focus on functional coating of graphite anode and the transport mechanism of Li+ in solid electrolyte interphase. Le Chen received her B.S. degree from Southwest University of Science and Technology in 2018. Now he is a master candidate in State Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Energy Materials, Southwest University of Science and Technology under the supervision of associate Prof. Lixian Song and Prof. Yingze Song. His research interests centre on advanced carbon materials for energy storage applications. Lixian Song received her Ph.D. from University of Science and Technology of China in 2017 under the supervision of Prof. Liangbin Li. Now she is an associate professor in State Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Energy Materials, Southwest University of Science and Technology. Her current research interests focus on in-situ/operando synchrotron-based characterization techniques. Yingze Song obtained his Ph.D. from Soochow University in 2019 under the supervision of Prof. Zhongfan Liu and Prof. Jingyu Sun. During 2013–2015, he worked in Ningbo Institute of Materials Technology & Engineering, CAS. Since July 2019, he became a Distinguished Professor and doctoral supervisor in State Key Laboratory of Environment-Friendly Energy Materials, Southwest University of Science and Technology. His current research interests deal with advanced material design for energy storage systems.

coredata.dc:description: Li–S batteries have been considered as one of advanced next-generation energy storage systems owing to their remarkable theoretical capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and high energy density (2600 Wh kg−1). However, critical issues, mainly pertaining to lithium polysulfide shuttle and slow sulfur reaction kinetics, have posed a fatal threat to the electrochemical performances of Li–S batteries. The situation is even worse for high sulfur-loaded and flexible cathodes, which are the essential components for practical Li–S batteries. In response, the use of metal compounds as electrocatalysts in Li–S systems have been confirmed as an effective strategy to date. Particularly, recent years have witnessed many progresses in phosphides-optimized Li–S chemistry. This has been motivated by the superior electron conductivity and high electrocatalytic activity of phosphides. In this tutorial review, we offer a systematic summary of active metal phosphides as promoters for Li–S chemistry, aiming at helping to understanding the working mechanism of phosphide electrocatalysts and guiding the construction of advanced Li–S batteries.
